III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family
Description time for each child in foster care consistent with the child's
service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to ensure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker (FCW1) was aware a respondent parent was
having contact with their child who is in care while in a relative
placement and did not take action for months.
Investigation Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via telephone on
March 5, 2024. She stated FCW1 is no longer with the agency but
does not have any reason to believe he was aware Complainant
was allowing unsupervised visits to occur between Youth A and
his biological mother.
She stated the Complainant filed an appeal with the Foster Care
Review Board (FCRB) and the hearing was today. A forwarded
email from FCRB was received from CA later in the day
documenting FCRB agreed with the agency’s decision to move
Youth A from Complainant’s home. She believes the allegations
are due to Complainant being upset about the agency’s decision
to move Youth A from her home.
Foster care worker 2 (FCW2) was interviewed via telephone
on March 8, 2024. She stated she was recently promoted to a
supervisor position but her role in this case was as a lead foster
care worker when FCW1 left the agency at the end of November
2023. She has assisted on and off since that time.
FCW2 stated she wanted to change the location of parenting time
visits from Complainant’s house back to the office on a temporary
basis due to her being unfamiliar with the case and since it was
going to termination, she wanted to see how the visits were going.
In addition, Complainant has previously expressed safety
concerns regarding Youth A’s biological mother. Biological mother
was notified visits would be temporarily moving to the agency
office, and she stated she did not agree with the decision and had
already been having unsupervised visits with Youth A for over a
2

year. Biological mother proceeded to provide FCW2 with
screenshots of text messages between Complainant and Youth
A’s biological mother. The text messages appear to show
Complainant coordinating unsupervised visits with Youth A’s
biological mother on several occasions. FCW2 contacted
Complainant and inquired about whether or not unsupervised
visits were occurring to which Complainant denied this was
happening. FCW2 conducted a home visit on February 15, 2024,
and again inquired about unsupervised visits. Complainant again
denied this was occurring but when FCW2 advised she had text
messages that indicated otherwise, Complainant then admitted it
was true and this had been occurring as early as October 2023,
but potentially earlier. Complainant also stated to FCW2 that
FCW1 was aware she was allowing unsupervised contact
between Youth A and biological mother to occur. FCW2 indicated
she is not sure whether or not this is accurate based on
Complainant’s history of not being forthcoming.
Foster care worker 1 (FCW1) was interviewed via telephone
on March 11, 2024. He stated he was the assigned caseworker
for Youth A’s case from the time of removal until the end of
November 2023. During his time as Youth A’s caseworker, he had
no knowledge or suspicion Complainant was allowing
unsupervised visits to occur between Youth A and his biological
mother. He stated Complainant was a designee and was allowed
to supervise the visits between Youth A and his biological mother.
When visits occurred Complainant would send him a text
message 1-2 times per week to notify him that a visit occurred and
provided a brief summary to let him know if there were any
concerns.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on March 11,
2024. She stated Youth A was placed with her for a year and a
half from the time he was removed from his biological mother until
the end of February. She stated she allowed unsupervised contact
to occur between Youth A and his biological mother beginning
approximately October 2023 until February 2024. She did not
notify FCW1 that this occurred, and she does not believe he knew
it was occurring.
Foster Care supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on March 14, 2024. She stated she had previously
worked at the agency, left and came back. When she came back,
she became the supervisor. She was not signing off on reports but
did a lot of the job functions as far as oversight with staff, including
FCW1. FC Supervisor stated it was made clear to Complainant
3

that all visits needed to be supervised. A DHS investigation was
opened at one point and during that time parenting time was
supervised at the agency. She stated she reiterated
Complainant’s role and responsibility as a designee on numerous
occasions. She stated there is nothing to suggest FCW1 was
aware Complainant was allowing unsupervised visits to occur.
Documents reviewed:
• Court order dated November 7, 2023. Complainant and
biological mother present. Order states parenting time is
supervised until further notice. Court order dated February
12, 2024. Complainant and biological mother present.
Order states parenting time is supervised until further
notice.
• Parenting time social work contacts were reviewed during
date range September 1, 2023-February 29, 2024. 19 total
contacts were reviewed. Contacts indicated parenting time
occurred as a designee visit/supervision. There were no
contacts entered for November 2023.
• Placement record: Youth A was placed in Complainant’s
home from November 10, 2022-February 26, 2024.
• November 27, 2023, USP visitation plan: twice per week
supervised visits. Parenting time supervised by designee
occurs at relative’s home or parental home. February 25,
2024, USP visitation plan: parenting times are court
ordered to be supervised. Parenting time can occur when
supervised by the agency or designee.
Analysis After conducting interviews and reviewing Youth A’s MISACWIS
case file the agency is found in compliance as there is no
evidence to support the allegations. Complainant and FCW1 both
stated during their interviews that FCW1 was not aware
Complainant was allowing unsupervised contact to occur.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
Description suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
4

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker is intimidating relative.
Investigation Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via telephone on
March 5, 2024. She stated the Complainant filed an appeal with
the Foster Care Review Board (FCRB) and the hearing was today.
A forwarded email from FCRB was received from CA later in the
day documenting FCRB agreed with the agency’s decision to
move Youth A from Complainant’s home. She believes the
allegations are due to Complainant being upset about the
agency’s decision to move Youth A from her home.
Foster care worker 2 (FCW2) was interviewed via telephone
on March 8, 2024. She stated she was recently promoted to a
supervisor position but her role in this case was as a lead foster
care worker when FCW1 left the agency at the end of November
2023. She has assisted on an off since that time.
She stated she conducted one home visit while in her previous
role and that took place in February. She stated she wanted to
change parenting time visits from Complainant’s house back to
the office on a temporary basis since she was unfamiliar with the
case and since it was going to termination, she wanted to see how
the visits were going. In addition, Complainant has previously
expressed safety concerns regarding Youth A’s biological mother.
Upon notifying biological mother that visits would be temporarily
moving to the agency office she notified FCW2 she did not agree
and had already been having unsupervised visits with Youth A for
over a year. Biological mother proceeded to provide FCW2 with
screenshots of text messages between Complainant and Youth
A’s biological mother. The text messages appear to show
Complainant was coordinating unsupervised visits with Youth A’s
biological mother on several occasions. FCW2 contacted
Complainant and inquired about whether or not unsupervised
visits were occurring to which Complainant denied that was
happening. FCW2 conducted a home visit on February 15, 2024,
and again inquired about unsupervised visits. Complainant again
denied this was occurring but when FCW2 advised she had text
messages that indicated otherwise, Complainant then admitted it
was true and had been occurring as early as October 2023, but
potentially earlier. Complainant also stated to FCW2 that FCW1
did not regularly visit Youth A in her home and was aware that she
was allowing unsupervised contact between Youth A and
biological mother to occur.
A Family Team Meeting (FTM) took place on February 19, 2024,
to discuss the concerns regarding Complainant allowing
5

unsupervised visits. During the meeting it was decided Youth A
would be moved to another placement. While seeking out another
placement for Youth A, the safety plan included making regular
visits to Complainant’s house. During this time, the agency was
made aware Complainant had made statements that she wanted
to harm herself. As a result, Youth A was moved immediately.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on March 11,
2024. She stated Youth A was placed with her for a year and a
half from the time he was removed from his biological mother until
the end of February. She stated she allowed unsupervised contact
to occur between Youth A and his biological mother beginning
approximately October 2023 until February 2024. She did not
notify FCW1 that this occurred, and she does not believe he knew
it was occurring.
She stated she was present at the FTM where the concerns were
discussed regarding unsupervised contact and the decision was
made to move Youth A to another foster placement. She was not
aware of the safety plan that staff would check in until a new
placement was found. She stated FCW2 was very rude,
unprofessional and intimidating in her interactions. When asked
for examples, she stated FCW2 referenced a text message she
had received regarding unsupervised contact but did not provide
the messages. On another occasion she conducted an
unannounced home visit. She stated FCW2 sent her a text
message one night at midnight and she felt that was
inappropriate.
Documents reviewed:
• FTM/TDM: TDM held virtually on February 20, 2024, in
regard to placement concerns. Concerns addressed
Complainant violating court order by allowing Youth A’s
biological mother to have unsupervised visits.
Recommendation is for Youth A to be moved to a new
placement. Safety plan is for FCW 2 to meet with Youth A
on a daily basis to verify his wellbeing until a new
placement can be found. Complainant is listed as being
present during FTM/TDM.
• February 21, 2024, social work contact: FCW2 conducted
an unannounced foster home visit in Youth A’s residence to
verify safety and well-being, due to presented safety
concerns of foster parent.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there is documentation
within Youth A’s MISACWIS case record that the contact between
6

FCW2 and Complainant was appropriate. FCW2 was made aware
of concerns Complainant was violating a court order by allowing
unsupervised contact between Youth A and his biological mother
and addressed them. Follow up contact with Complainant and
Youth A was made as part of a safety plan that was discussed in a
Family Team Meeting/Team Decision Making meeting where
Complaint was present and aware this would be occurring.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
